issue.title: What should async do if neither 'async' nor 'deferred' is set in policy?

discussion.p: Implementations already disagree, one returns an invalid future with no shared state, one chooses policy == async and one chooses policy == deferred, see c++std-lib-30839, c++std-lib-30840 and c++std-lib-30844. It's not clear if returning an invalid future is allowed by the current wording.
If the intention is to allow an empty future to be returned, then p3 and p4 should be adjusted to clarify that a shared state might not be created and an invalid future might be returned.
If the intention is that a valid future is always returned, p3 should say something about the case where none of the conditions applies.
We could make it undefined if no launch policy is defined.
Hans: If no launch policy is specified the behaviour is undefined
Hans: no: we don't want people to do this
This wording is relative to N3376
Add a third bullet to the end of the list in 30.6.8p3
discussion.blockquote: "if no valid launch policy is provided the behaviour is undefined"

blockquote.note: This wording is relative to N3376
blockquote.p: Add a third bullet to the end of the list in p3

blockquote.ins: – if no valid launch policy is provided the behaviour is undefined

discussion.p: If no policy is given, it should be undefined, so moved to Immediate.

resolution.note: This wording is relative to N3485
resolution.p: Add a third bullet to the end of the list in p3

blockquote.ins: – If no value is set in the launch policy, or a value is set that is neither specified in this International Standard or by the implementation, the behaviour is undefined.
